newsitem.title: JAPAN: INTERVIEW - Dai-Ichi Life keeps foreign bond plan.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - Dai-Ichi Life keeps foreign bond plan.

text.p: The recent fall in the dollar has not forced Dai-Ichi Mutual Life Insurance Co to alter its plan to invest about 300 billion yen in foreign bonds in fiscal 1997/98.

Shingo Uchiyama, the manager of Dai-Ichi's international fixed income investment section, told Reuters in an interview that the insurer was looking for a good time to buy the bonds as the basic bullish trend of the dollar had not changed.

"I think seven percent (for 30-year U.S. Treasury bond) is probably the right time to buy U.S. Treasuries," Uchiyama said. Uchiyama said that longer-end T-bond yields are not expected to rise above 7.0 percent as many market participants are showing buying interest in bonds at around that level.
Dai-Ichi Life bought 500 billion yen worth of foreign bonds in 1996/97, boosting the total value of its foreign bond portfolio to one trillion yen, Uchiyama said.
The interest rate differential between Japan and the United States of above four percent is high enough to make overseas investment an attractive option, Uchiyama said.

The gap between the yield of the key 10-year Japanese government bond, which currently stands at 2.580 percent, and the key 10-year U.S. Treasury note, which was at 6.75 percent in late Asian trade, is about 4.17 percent.
Uchiyama said that about 90 percent of Dai-Ichi Life's foreign bonds is held in U.S. dollars and German marks.

He said the company increased its investments in foreign bonds that are denominated in high-yielding currencies like the Canadian dollar and the British pound in 1996/97 in an attempt to acquire higher returns.
"We have lowered our forecast for the dollar/yen to a range of 110-120 yen, but our basic foreign bond investment plan has not changed at this point," Uchiyama said.
"After the dollar's recent plunge, the market now seems to have calmed down and steadied at around 115 yen," he said.
The dollar fell to a five-month low of 111.98 yen on Tuesday, down some 12 percent from its recent peak of 127.47 yen set on May 1. It was at 115.70/80 yen late on Friday.
Currency and bond traders said Japanese life insurers have been generally quiet since the beginning of the new fiscal year and also limited their sales during the dollar's recent tumble.
Uchiyama, however, said that the company's investment stance is flexible and could change depending on the market trend.

He said that Dai-Ichi Life, which invested 500 billion yen in foreign bonds in the 1996/97 fiscal year, originally planned to cut its bond holdings by 50 billion yen at the beginning of the the fiscal year.
Meanwhile, the company is planning to diversify its foreign bond investment from the current fiscal year by buying U.S. and Asian corporate bonds, Uchiyama said.
"We aim to invest about 10 billion yen for each (U.S. and Asian corporate bonds) to start with," he said.
